title.narrative: Support for the Malaria World Congress

description.narrative: Australia’s health security is linked to the health security of countries in the Indo-Pacific region – in an inter-connected world diseases do not respect borders. A major disease outbreak could have severe health and economic implications for all countries in the region, including Australia, potentially disrupting trade, investment and people movement, and setting back growth and development. In the Indo-Pacific, such threats include highly pathogenic avian influenza and drug-resistant forms of tuberculosis and malaria. A gap in the malaria response landscape is the absence of a forum where representatives from across the entire malaria world can meet. To address this, the World Malaria Congress (MWC) will be held in Melbourne on 1-5 July 2018. The WMC will bring together researchers, implementers, funders, representative multilateral bodies, government agencies, parliamentary groups, civil society organisations, and affected community representatives.
